sen.j: 額安寺（かくあんじ）は奈良県大和郡山市額田部寺町（ぬかたべてらまち）にある真言律宗の寺院である。
sen.e: Kakuan-ji Temple is a temple of Shingon Ritsu sect located in Nukatabeteramachi, Yamatokoriyama City, Nara Prefecture.
Kakuan-ji Temple is a temple belonging to the Shingon Ritsu sect of Buddhism, located in Nukatabetera-machi, Yamatokoriyama City, Nara Prefecture.
Kakuan-ji Temple is a temple belonging to the Shingon Ritsu sect of Buddhism, located in Nukatabetera-machi, Yamatokoriyama City, Nara Prefecture.

sen.j: 山号は熊凝山（くまごりさん）。
sen.e: Its honorific mountain prefix is Kumagorisan.
Its sango (literally "mountain name", a title prefixed to the name of a Buddhist temple) is Kumagorisan.
Its sango (literally "mountain name", a title prefixed to the name of a Buddhist temple) is Kumagorisan.

sen.j: 本尊は十一面観音。
sen.e: The principal image is Eleven-faced Kannon.
Its principal image is of an Eleven-faced Kannon.
Its principal image is of an Eleven-faced Kannon.

sen.j: 寺名は「がくあんじ」ではなく「かくあんじ」と呼ばれている。
sen.e: The temple name is called as "Kakuan-ji", instead of "Gakuan-ji".
The temple name is pronounced "Kakuan-ji" rather than "Gakuan-ji".
The temple name is pronounced "Kakuan-ji" rather than "Gakuan-ji".

sen.j: 大和郡山市の南端近く、大和川と佐保川の合流地点付近に位置する。
sen.e: This temple is located around the confluence of Yamato River and Saho River, near the south end of Yamatokoriyama City.
This temple is located around the confluence of the Yamato and Saho rivers, near the south end of Yamatokoriyama City.
This temple is located around the confluence of the Yamato and Saho rivers, near the south end of Yamatokoriyama City.

sen.j: 飛鳥時代に聖徳太子の建立と伝えられ、大安寺の前身である熊凝精舎（くまごりしょうじゃ）跡ともいわれるが、実際にはこの地を本拠としていた豪族額田部（ぬかたべ）氏の氏寺として建立されたものと思われる。
sen.e: It is said to be erected in the Asuka period by Prince Shotoku, and also the remains of Kumagori shoja Temple, the former Daian-ji Temple, but actually, considered to be erected as the Uji-dera Temple (temple built for praying clan's glory) for the local ruling family, Nukatabe clan, who was based in this land.

It is said to have been erected in the Asuka Period by Prince Shotoku, and some say that the remains of Kumagori Shoja Temple, the temple previously built at the current location of Daian-ji Temple, are of it, but actually, it is accepted that it was erected to be the Uji-dera temple (temple built to pray for the glory of a clan) for the local ruling family, the Nukatabe clan, who were based in this area.
sen.cmt: Changed for clarity, made a sentence, grammar, punctuation.
sen.e: It is said to have been erected in the Asuka Period by Prince Shotoku, and some say that the remains of Kumagori Shoja Temple, the temple previously built at the current location of Daian-ji Temple, are of it, but actually, it is accepted that it was erected to be the Uji-dera temple (temple built to pray for the glory of a clan) for the local ruling family, the Nukatabe clan, who were based in this area.

sen.j: 天平19年（747年）の『大安寺伽藍縁起並流記資財帳』（だいあんじがらんえんぎならびにるきしざいちょう、国立歴史民俗博物館蔵）によれば、南都七大寺の1つである大安寺の前身は、聖徳太子が額田部の地に建立した熊凝精舎であって、これが後に移転と改称を繰り返した後、平城京の大安寺となったという。
sen.e: According to "Daianji Garan Engi narabini Ruki Shizai Cho" (The History of Daian-ji Temple and the record of the estates, National Museum of Japanese History) in 747, the predecessor of Daian-ji Temple, one of the Seven Great Temples in Nara, was Kumagori shoja Temple erected in Nukatabe's land by Prince Shotoku, which became Daian-ji Temple in Heijo-kyo after repeated relocations and renamings.

According to "Daianji Garan Engi narabini Ruki Shizai Cho" (The History of Daian-ji Temple and the Record of the Estates, held at the National Museum of Japanese History) in 747, the predecessor of Daian-ji Temple, one of the Seven Great Temples of Nara, was Kumagori Shoja Temple erected in Nukatabe's land by Prince Shotoku, which became Daian-ji Temple in Heijo-kyo after repeated relocations and renamings.

According to "Daianji Garan Engi narabini Ruki Shizai Cho" (The History of Daian-ji Temple and the Record of the Estates, held at the National Museum of Japanese History) in 747, the predecessor of Daian-ji Temple, one of the Seven Great Temples of Nara, was Kumagori Shoja Temple erected in Nukatabe's land by Prince Shotoku, which became Daian-ji Temple in Heijo-kyo after repeated relocations and renamings.

sen.j: しかし、熊凝精舎を大安寺の前身とする説は他に裏づけとなる史料がなく、疑問視されている。
sen.e: However,the theory that Kumagori shoja Temple was former Daian-ji Temple is in question without other supporting historical materials.
However, the theory that Kumagori Shoja Temple and Daian-ji Temple are the same is open to question without evidence from other supporting historical sources.
However, the theory that Kumagori Shoja Temple and Daian-ji Temple are the same is open to question without evidence from other supporting historical sources.

sen.j: 大安寺の平城京移建に貢献した僧・道慈が額田部氏出身であることから、このような説が生じたのではないかとも言われる。
sen.e: It is also said that such theory was raised because the monk Doji who contributed to transfer of Daian-ji Temple to Heijo-kyo was from the Nukatabe clan.
It is also said that such a theory was put forward because the monk Doji who contributed to the transfer of Daian-ji Temple to Heijo-kyo was from the Nukatabe clan.
It is also said that such a theory was put forward because the monk Doji who contributed to the transfer of Daian-ji Temple to Heijo-kyo was from the Nukatabe clan.

sen.j: かつて額安寺に伝来し，現在では国立歴史民俗博物館に所蔵される「額田寺伽藍並条里図（ぬかたでらがらんならびにじょうりず、国宝）」によれば、奈良時代には金堂・講堂・三重塔が建ち並び、大いに栄えていたようである。
sen.e: According to "Nukatabedera Garan narabini Jori Zu (The picture of Nukatabe-ji Temple and the streets, National Treasure)" having been introduced to Kakuan-ji Temple and now in National Museum of Japanese History, during the Nara period, Golden hall/Lecture hall/three-story pagoda were built one after another and it seemed to be flourished.

According to "Nukatabedera Garan narabini Jori Zu" (Pictures of Nukatabe-ji Temple and the Streets, a National Treasure) passed down through the generations at Kakuan-ji Temple and now in the National Museum of Japanese History, during the Nara Period, the Golden Hall, lecture hall and three-story pagoda were built one after another and it flourished greatly.

According to "Nukatabedera Garan narabini Jori Zu" (Pictures of Nukatabe-ji Temple and the Streets, a National Treasure) passed down through the generations at Kakuan-ji Temple and now in the National Museum of Japanese History, during the Nara Period, the Golden Hall, lecture hall and three-story pagoda were built one after another and it flourished greatly.

sen.j: この伽藍並条里図は、画面に記入されている人名等から天平宝字年間（757 - 765年）頃の作成と推定され、額田寺（額安寺）の創建がこれ以前であることを裏付けている。
sen.e: This Garan narabini Jori Zu was presumed to be painted during around the Tenpyo-Hoji era (757-765), from the name etc. inscribed on the picture plane, supporting that foundation of Nukata-dera Temple (Kakuan-ji Temple) was earlier than that period.

This Garan narabini Jori Zu was presumed to have been painted in around the Tenpyo-Hoji era (757-765) from the name and other details inscribed on the picture plane, supporting the theory that the foundation of Nukata-dera Temple (Kakuan-ji Temple) was earlier than this period.

This Garan narabini Jori Zu was presumed to have been painted in around the Tenpyo-Hoji era (757-765) from the name and other details inscribed on the picture plane, supporting the theory that the foundation of Nukata-dera Temple (Kakuan-ji Temple) was earlier than this period.

sen.j: 平安時代には寺勢が衰えたが、鎌倉後期に西大寺の叡尊・忍性らにより再興された。
sen.e: It went into decline in the Heian period, but revived by Eison, Ninsho and others of Saidai-ji Temple in the late Kamakura Period.
It went into decline in the Heian Period, but was revived by Eison, Ninsho and others of Saidai-ji Temple in the late Kamakura Period.
It went into decline in the Heian Period, but was revived by Eison, Ninsho and others of Saidai-ji Temple in the late Kamakura Period.

sen.j: 室町時代には兵乱によって再び荒廃した。
sen.e: It was ruined again by disturbance of the war in the Muromachi period.
It was ruined again as a consequence of war in the Muromachi Period.
It was ruined again as a consequence of war in the Muromachi Period.

sen.j: 天正8年、信長検地で寺領180石を没収される。
sen.e: In 1580, the temple estate 180-koku was forfeited in Nobunaga's land survey.
sen.cmt: 西暦の記載がなかったため， wikipediaで確認しました。
sen.e: In 1580, the 180-koku temple estate was forfeited as a result of Nobunaga's land survey.
In 1580, the 180-koku temple estate was forfeited as a result of Nobunaga's land survey.

sen.j: 後に豊臣秀吉により四天王寺へ五重塔を譲ることと引き換えに寺領一町歩が与えられて再興された。
sen.e: It was restored later by Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI at the temple's estate of approximately 1 ha. given in exchange for handover of five-story pagoda to Shitenno-ji Temple.
This was restored later by Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI as the temple's estate of approximately a hectares was received in exchange for a five-story pagoda which was given to Shitenno-ji Temple.
This was restored later by Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI as the temple's estate of approximately a hectares was received in exchange for a five-story pagoda which was given to Shitenno-ji Temple.

sen.j: 江戸時代には寺領12石を公認された。
sen.e: In the Edo period, the temple estate 12-koku was officially recognized.
In the Edo Period, the 12-koku temple estate was officially recognized.
In the Edo Period, the 12-koku temple estate was officially recognized.

sen.j: 木心乾漆虚空蔵菩薩半跏像 - 奈良時代-平安時代初期の作
sen.e: Wood-core dry lacquer statue of Akasagarbha Bodhisattva sitting in the half lotus position - Nara period - carved in the early Heian period
A wood-core dry lacquer statue of Akasagarbha Bodhisattva sitting in the half lotus position, made at the end of the Nara Period or the beginning of the Heian Period
A wood-core dry lacquer statue of Akasagarbha Bodhisattva sitting in the half lotus position, made at the end of the Nara Period or the beginning of the Heian Period

sen.j: 五輪塔 8基 - 寺の北側の境外墓地に立つ。
sen.e: 8 Gorintos (a gravestone composed of five pieces piled up one upon another) - standing in the outside cemetery at the north of the temple.
Eight gorinto (a gravestone in the form of a tower composed of five sections set one upon another), found outside the cemetery at the north of the temple
Eight gorinto (a gravestone in the form of a tower composed of five sections set one upon another), found outside the cemetery at the north of the temple

sen.j: うち2基に永仁5年（1297年）銘がある。
sen.e: Two of them were engraved with the year 1297.
Two of them were engraved with the year 1297.
Two of them were engraved with the year 1297.

sen.j: 五輪塔納置品
sen.e: The items within the Gorintos
Items within the gorinto
Items within the gorinto

sen.j: 昭和57年（1982年）の五輪塔修理の際に見出されたもの。
sen.e: Found when the Gorintos were repaired in 1982.
These were found when the gorinto were repaired in 1982.
These were found when the gorinto were repaired in 1982.

sen.j: 鎌倉極楽寺 (鎌倉市)開山の良観上人忍性（嘉元元年/1303年没）ならびに忍性の弟子で極楽寺3世の善願上人順忍（嘉暦元年/1326年）の骨蔵器などの一括遺品である。
sen.e: A set of mementos such as the cinerary urn of Ryokan-Shonin Ninsho, the founding priest of Kamakura gokuraku-ji Temple (Kamakura City) (died in 1303) and Zengan-Shonin Junnin, Ninsho's disciple and the 3rd chief priest of Gokuraku-ji Temple (1326).

A set of mementos such as the cinerary urn of Ryokan-Shonin Ninsho, the founding priest of Kamakura gokuraku-ji Temple (Kamakura City) who died in 1303, and that of Zengan-Shonin Junnin, Ninsho's disciple and the third chief priest of Gokuraku-ji Temple from 1326.

A set of mementos such as the cinerary urn of Ryokan-Shonin Ninsho, the founding priest of Kamakura gokuraku-ji Temple (Kamakura City) who died in 1303, and that of Zengan-Shonin Junnin, Ninsho's disciple and the third chief priest of Gokuraku-ji Temple from 1326.

sen.j: 忍性は鎌倉時代に戒律復興と社会事業に努めた僧で、その遺骨は極楽寺、額安寺、生駒の竹林寺 (生駒市)の3か所に分骨された。
sen.e: Ninsho was a monk who put great efforts for revival of religious precept and social work in the Kamakura Period, and his ashes were buried at 3 places, Gokuraku-ji Temple, Kakuan-ji Temple and Chikurin-ji in Ikoma (Ikoma City).

Ninsho was a monk who made great efforts to revive religious precepts and did work to benefit society during the Kamakura Period, and his ashes were buried in three places, Gokuraku-ji Temple, Kakuan-ji Temple and Chikurin-ji in Ikoma (Ikoma City).

Ninsho was a monk who made great efforts to revive religious precepts and did work to benefit society during the Kamakura Period, and his ashes were buried in three places, Gokuraku-ji Temple, Kakuan-ji Temple and Chikurin-ji in Ikoma (Ikoma City).

sen.j: 忍性の骨蔵器は瓶子のような独特の形のもので、竹林寺の忍性墓からも、額安寺のものと同形式の銅骨蔵器が出土している。
sen.e: Ninsho's cinerary urn has a unique shape like a liquor bottle, and a bronze urn of the same type as that from Kakuan-ji Temple was also excavated from the tomb of Ninsho in Chikurin-ji Temple.
Ninsho's cinerary urn has a unique shape like a liquor bottle, and a bronze urn of the same type as that from Kakuan-ji Temple was also excavated from the tomb of Ninsho in Chikurin-ji Temple.
Ninsho's cinerary urn has a unique shape like a liquor bottle, and a bronze urn of the same type as that from Kakuan-ji Temple was also excavated from the tomb of Ninsho in Chikurin-ji Temple.

tit.e: Cultural Properties formerly held by Kakuan-ji Temple
Cultural Properties formerly held by Kakuan-ji Temple
Cultural Properties formerly held by Kakuan-ji Temple

sen.j: （国宝）額田寺伽藍並条里図（国立歴史民俗博物館蔵）
sen.e: (National Treasure) Nukatabedera Garan narabini Jori Zu (The picture of Nukatabe-ji Temple and the streets) (National Museum of Japanese History)
Nukatabedera Garan narabini Jori Zu (Pictures of Nukatabe-ji Temple and the Streets) is a National Treasure kept at the National Museum of Japanese History.
Nukatabedera Garan narabini Jori Zu (Pictures of Nukatabe-ji Temple and the Streets) is a National Treasure kept at the National Museum of Japanese History.

sen.j: （重要文化財）黒漆小龕（首懸駄都種子曼荼羅厨子）（奈良国立博物館蔵）
sen.e: (Important Cultural Property) Small black-lacquered altar (Kubikake Dazushuji Mandara Zushi [The cabinet which has two rings to tie with the cord and on which the mandara is painted, the mandara represents the seeds of Mahavairocana.]) (Nara National Museum)

Important Cultural Properties include a small black-lacquered altar called Kubikake Dazushuji Mandara Zushi, a cabinet which has two rings tied with cord and on which the mandala is painted, the mandala reflecting the seeds of Mahavairocana (Nara National Museum).

Important Cultural Properties include a small black-lacquered altar called Kubikake Dazushuji Mandara Zushi, a cabinet which has two rings tied with cord and on which the mandala is painted, the mandala reflecting the seeds of Mahavairocana (Nara National Museum).

sen.j: （重要文化財）木造文殊菩薩騎獅像（文化庁）
sen.e: (Important Cultural Property) Wooden Statue of Monju Bosatsu Riding on a Lion (Agency for Cultural Affairs)
The wooden statue of Monju Bosatsu riding on a lion is also an Important Cultural Property and is held by the Agency for Cultural Affairs.
The wooden statue of Monju Bosatsu riding on a lion is also an Important Cultural Property and is held by the Agency for Cultural Affairs.

sen.j: 近鉄橿原線平端駅より徒歩約10分
sen.e: Walk for approximately 10 minutes from Kintetsu Kashihara Line Hirahata Station
Walk for approximately ten minutes from Hirahata Station on the Kintetsu Kashihara Line.
Walk for approximately ten minutes from Hirahata Station on the Kintetsu Kashihara Line.

sen.j: 大和郡山市額田部寺町36
sen.e: 36 Nukatabeteramachi, Yamatokoriyama City
